pairs.stoic_text:
If the professors of virtue be as the world calls them, avaricious,
libidinous, ambitious—what are they then that have a detestation for
the very name of it: but malicious natures do not want wit to abuse
honester men than themselves. It is the practice of the multitude to
bark at eminent men as little dogs do at strangers; for they look upon
other men’s virtues as the upbraiding of their own wickedness. We
should do well to commend those that are good, if not, let us pass them
over; but, however, let us spare ourselves: for beside the blaspheming
of virtue, our rage is to no purpose. But to return now to my text.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here is the same text rewritten in plain language:

If teachers of morality are greedy, lustful, and power-hungry as people say they are, then what does that make those who hate the very idea of virtue? Evil people are clever enough to attack those who are more honest than they are. Most people criticize prominent individuals the way small dogs bark at strangers - they see other people's good qualities as criticism of their own bad behavior. We should praise good people when we can, or at least ignore them if we can't. Either way, we should control ourselves, because attacking virtue is pointless and also harms our own reputation. Now let me return to my main topic.

pairs.stoic_text:
A good and a wise man is not to be an _enemy_ of wicked men, but a
_reprover_ of them; and he is to look upon all the drunkards, the
lustful, the thankless, covetous, and ambitious, that he meets with,
not otherwise than as a physician looks upon his patients; for he that
will be angry with _any man_ must be displeased with _all_; which were
as ridiculous as to quarrel with a body for stumbling in the dark; with
one that is deaf, for not doing as you bid him; or with a school-boy
for loving his play better than his book. Democritus _laughed_, and
Heraclitus _wept_, at the folly and wickedness of the world, but we
never read of any _angry philosopher_.
pairs.neutral_text: A good and wise person should not be an enemy of bad people, but should correct them instead. When he encounters people who drink too much, are sexually immoral, ungrateful, greedy, or power-hungry, he should view them the same way a doctor views sick patients. Anyone who gets angry at one person would have to be angry at everyone, which would be as foolish as getting mad at someone for tripping in the dark, being upset with a deaf person for not following instructions, or being angry at a child for preferring games over studying. Democritus responded to human foolishness and evil by laughing, while Heraclitus responded by crying, but there are no records of any philosopher responding with anger.

pairs.stoic_text:
In the first place, Anger is _unwarrantable_ as it is _unjust_: for it
falls many times upon the wrong person, and discharges itself upon the
innocent instead of the guilty: beside the disproportion of making the
most trivial offences to be capital, and punishing an inconsiderate
word perhaps with torments, fetters, infamy, or death. It allows a man
neither time nor means for defence, but judges a cause without hearing
it, and admits of no mediation. It flies into the face of truth itself,
if it be of the adverse party; and turns obstinacy in an error, into
an argument of justice. It does every thing with agitation and tumult;
whereas reason and equity can destroy whole families, if there be
occasion for it, even to the extinguishing of their names and memories,
without any indecency, either of countenance or action.
pairs.neutral_text:
Anger is unjustifiable because it is unfair. It often targets the wrong person, punishing innocent people instead of guilty ones. It also treats minor offenses as if they were serious crimes, sometimes punishing a careless comment with torture, imprisonment, public shame, or death.

Anger doesn't give people time or opportunity to defend themselves. It makes judgments without hearing all the evidence and refuses to consider compromise. If the truth contradicts what anger wants to believe, anger rejects the truth. It treats stubborn refusal to admit mistakes as if this were moral righteousness.

Anger acts with chaos and disorder. In contrast, reason and fairness can destroy entire families when necessary - even erasing their names from history - while remaining calm and appropriate in behavior and expression.

pairs.stoic_text:
We cannot close up this chapter with a more generous instance of
moderation than that of Fabricius. Pyrrhus tempted him with a sum of
money to betray his country, and Pyrrhus’s physician offered Fabricius,
for a sum of money, to poison his _master_; but he was too brave
either to be overcome by gold, or to be overcome by poison, so that he
refused the money, and advised Pyrrhus to have a care of treachery:
and this too in the heat of a licentious war. Fabricius valued himself
upon his poverty, and was as much above the thought of riches as of
poison. “Live Pyrrhus,” says he “by my friendship; and turn that to
thy satisfaction which was before thy trouble:” that is to say that
Fabricius could not be corrupted.
pairs.neutral_text: This chapter ends with a good example of moderation from Fabricius. Pyrrhus tried to bribe Fabricius with money to betray his country, and Pyrrhus's doctor offered to poison Pyrrhus in exchange for payment from Fabricius. However, Fabricius was too honorable to accept either bribery or assassination. He rejected the money and warned Pyrrhus about the doctor's treachery, even though they were enemies during wartime. Fabricius was proud of being poor and had no interest in wealth or underhanded tactics. He told Pyrrhus to live and benefit from their friendship instead of seeing it as a problem. This shows that Fabricius could not be bought or corrupted.

pairs.stoic_text:
What can be happier than the condition both of mind and of fortune from
which we cannot fall—what can be a greater felicity than in a covetous,
designing age, for a roan to live safe among informers and thieves? It
puts a poor man into the very condition of Providence, that gives all,
without reserving anything to itself. How happy is he that owes nothing
but to himself, and only that which he can easily refuse or easily
pay! I do not reckon him poor that has but a little, but he is so that
covets more—it is a fair degree of plenty to have what is necessary.
Whether had a man better find satiety in want, or hunger in plenty? It
is not the augmenting of our fortunes, but the abating of our appetites
that makes us rich.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here is the text rewritten in plain language:

The best situation is when you have both peace of mind and financial security that cannot be taken away from you. In a time when people are greedy and scheming, it is very valuable for someone to live safely among people who might betray others or steal from them. A poor person who gives everything away is similar to God, who provides for everyone without keeping anything back. Someone is fortunate when they only depend on themselves and only owe what they can either easily refuse to pay or easily afford to pay. I don't consider someone poor just because they have little money - someone is poor when they always want more than they have. Having enough to meet your basic needs is a good amount to have. Is it better to feel satisfied when you have little, or to feel hungry for more when you have plenty? We become wealthy not by getting more money, but by wanting less.

pairs.stoic_text:
But it is a great error to take this passion either for a companion
or for an assistant to virtue; that makes a man incapable of those
necessary counsels by which virtue is to govern herself. Those are
false and inauspicious powers, and destructive of themselves, which
arise only from the accession and fervor of disease. Reason judges
according to right; anger will have every thing seem right, whatever it
does, and when it has once pitched upon a mistake, it is never to be
convinced, but prefers a pertinacity, even in the greatest evil, before
the most necessary repentance.
pairs.neutral_text: It is a big mistake to think that anger helps or supports good behavior. Anger prevents a person from making the wise decisions that good behavior requires. Powers that come only from sickness and intense emotion are false, unlucky, and self-destructive. Reason makes correct judgments, but anger wants everything it does to appear correct. Once anger makes an error, it refuses to change its mind. Anger would rather stubbornly stick to even the worst mistakes than admit it was wrong and feel the regret that is sometimes necessary.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is truly and excellently spoken of Seneca, says Lactantius, once
again; “Consider,” says he “the majesty, the goodness, and the
venerable mercies of the Almighty; a friend that is always at hand.
What delight can it be to him the slaughter of innocent creatures or
the worship of bloody sacrifices? Let us purge our minds, and lead
virtuous and honest lives. His pleasure lies not in the magnificence of
temples made with stone, but in the pity and devotion of consecrated
hearts.”
pairs.neutral_text: Lactantius quotes Seneca again, saying that Seneca made an excellent point. Seneca said to think about God's power, kindness, and mercy - God is always available to help us. God does not enjoy the killing of innocent animals or bloody sacrifices. Instead, we should clean up our thoughts and live moral, honest lives. God is not pleased by expensive stone temples, but by compassionate and devoted hearts.

pairs.stoic_text:
This is undoubtedly the most detestable of vices, even compared with
the worst of them. Avarice scrapes and gathers together that which
somebody may be the better for: but anger lashes out, and no man comes
_off_ gratis. An angry master makes one servant run away, and another
hang himself; and his choler causes him a much greater loss than he
suffered in the occasion of it. It is the cause of mourning to the
father, and of divorce to the husband: it makes the magistrate odious,
and gives the candidate a repulse. And it is worse than luxury too,
which only aims at its proper pleasure; whereas the other is bent upon
another body’s pain.
pairs.neutral_text: This is certainly the worst vice, even when compared to other terrible vices. Greed collects and saves things that someone else might benefit from, but anger strikes out and harms everyone involved. An angry master causes one servant to flee and another to kill himself. His rage costs him much more than whatever originally upset him. Anger causes fathers to grieve and husbands to divorce. It makes government officials unpopular and causes political candidates to lose elections. Anger is also worse than excessive indulgence, which at least seeks personal pleasure, while anger deliberately tries to cause pain to others.

pairs.stoic_text:
And every jot as ridiculous, though not so impious, was that of Cyrus;
who, in his design upon Babylon, found a river in his way that put a
stop to his march: the current was strong, and carried away one of the
horses that belonged to his own chariot: upon this he swore, that since
it had obstructed _his_ passage, it should never hinder any body’s
else; and presently set his whole army to work upon it, which diverted
it into a hundred and fourscore channels, and laid it dry. In this
ignoble and unprofitable employment he lost his time, and the soldiers
their courage, and gave his adversaries an opportunity of providing
themselves, while he was waging war with a river instead of an enemy.
pairs.neutral_text:
Cyrus made an equally ridiculous decision, though it wasn't disrespectful to religion. When he was planning to attack Babylon, he encountered a river that blocked his army's path. The river had a strong current and swept away one of the horses from his personal chariot. This made Cyrus angry, so he declared that since the river had blocked his way, he would make sure it never blocked anyone else's path again. He immediately ordered his entire army to work on diverting the river into 180 separate channels until the original riverbed was completely dry.

This pointless project wasted valuable time and demoralized his soldiers. While Cyrus was fighting against a river instead of preparing to fight his actual enemies, his opponents had extra time to strengthen their defenses and get ready for battle.

pairs.stoic_text:
Lucilius tells me, that he was written to by a friend, but cautions
me withal not to say anything to him of the affair in question; for
he himself stands upon the same guard. What is this but to affirm and
to deny the same thing in the same breath, in calling a man a friend,
whom we dare not trust as our own soul? For there must be no reserves
in friendship: as much deliberation as you please before the league
is struck, but no doubtings or jealousies after. It is a preposterous
weakness to love a man before we know him, and not to care for him
after. It requires time to consider of a friendship, but the resolution
once taken, entitles him to my very heart. I look upon my thoughts to
be as safe in his breast as in my own: I shall, without any scruple,
make him the confidant of my most secret cares and counsels.
pairs.neutral_text:
Lucilius told me that a friend wrote to him, but he warned me not to mention a particular matter to this friend. He said he's being equally cautious himself. This creates a contradiction - he calls this person a friend while simultaneously not trusting him completely.

True friendship should have no secrets. You should think carefully before forming a friendship, but once you decide to be friends, you shouldn't have doubts or suspicions. It's backwards to love someone before you really know them, then stop caring about them later.

Friendship takes time to develop properly. But once I've decided to be someone's friend, I should trust them completely. I should feel as comfortable sharing my thoughts with them as I do keeping them to myself. I should be willing to tell them my most private concerns and ask for their advice without hesitation.

pairs.stoic_text:
What is it that we plow the seas for; or arm ourselves against men and
beasts? To what end do we toil, and labor, and pile bags upon bags? We
may enlarge our fortunes, but we cannot our bodies; so that it does
but spill and run over, whatsoever we take more than we can hold. Our
forefathers (by the force of whose virtues we are now supported in our
vices) lived every jot as well as we, when they provided and dressed
their own meat with their own hands; lodged upon the ground, and were
not as yet come to the vanity of gold and gems; when they swore by
their earthen gods, and kept their oath, though they died for it.
pairs.neutral_text:
Why do we travel across oceans for trade, or fight against people and animals? Why do we work hard and accumulate wealth? We can increase our money, but we cannot make our bodies bigger to use more than they need. Any excess just goes to waste since we can only use what our bodies require.

Our ancestors, who built the foundations that now allow us to live poorly despite our wealth, lived just as well as we do. They hunted and cooked their own food, slept on the ground, and did not care about gold and jewels. They made promises to their simple gods and kept those promises even when it cost them their lives.

pairs.stoic_text:
Horatius Cocles opposed his single body to the whole army until the
bridge was cut down behind him and then leaped into the river with his
sword in his hand and came off safe to his party. There was a fellow
questioned about a plot upon the life of a tyrant, and put to the
torture to declare his confederates: he named, by one and one, all the
tyrant’s friends that were about him: and still as they were named,
they were put to death: the tyrant asked him at last if there were any
more. “Yes,” says he, “yourself were in the plot; and now you have
never another friend left in the world:” whereupon the tyrant cut the
throats of his own guards. “He is the happy man that is the master of
himself, and triumphs over the fear of death, which has overcome the
conquerors of the world.”
pairs.neutral_text:
Horatius Cocles fought alone against an entire army while the bridge behind him was being destroyed. After it was cut down, he jumped into the river while still holding his sword and safely reached his allies.

There was a man who was questioned about a plan to kill a ruler. He was tortured to make him reveal who else was involved. He gave the names of all the ruler's friends and advisors one by one. Each person he named was then executed. Finally, the ruler asked if there were any other conspirators. The man replied, "Yes, you were part of the plot, and now you have no friends left alive." This caused the ruler to kill his own bodyguards.

A person who controls himself and is not afraid of death is truly successful, even more so than those who have conquered nations.

pairs.stoic_text:
There are many that lie close, not that they may live securely, but
that they may transgress more privately: it is their conscience, not
their states, that makes them keep a porter; for they live at such a
rate, that to be seen before they be aware is to be detected. Crates
saw a young man walking by himself; “Have a care,” says he “of lewd
company.” Some men are busy in idleness, and make peace more laborious
and troublesome than war; nay, and more wicked too, when they bestow it
upon such lusts, and other vices, which even the license of a military
life would not endure. We cannot call these people men of leisure that
are wholly taken up with their pleasures. A troublesome life is much
to be preferred before a slothful one; and it is a strange thing,
methinks, that any man should fear death that has buried himself alive;
as privacy without letters is but the burying of a man quick.
pairs.neutral_text:
Many people hide away not to live safely, but to commit wrongdoing in secret. Their guilty conscience, not their wealth, makes them isolate themselves, because they live in such a way that being seen unexpectedly means being caught doing something wrong. When Crates saw a young man walking alone, he warned him to "be careful of bad company" - meaning the company of his own thoughts.

Some people stay busy doing nothing productive, making peacetime more difficult and troublesome than wartime. They also make it more immoral when they spend their time on sexual desires and other vices that wouldn't even be tolerated during the looseness of military life. We can't call people who are completely focused on pleasures "people of leisure."

A difficult but productive life is much better than a lazy one. I find it strange that anyone would fear death when they have already buried themselves alive. Being alone without learning or intellectual activity is like being buried while still breathing.

pairs.stoic_text:
This is not to discountenance the veneration we owe to parents; nor
to make children the worse, but the better; and to stir up generous
emulations: for, in contests of good offices, both parties are happy;
as well the vanquished as those that overcome. It is the only honorable
dispute that can arise betwixt a father and son, which of the two
shall have the better of the other in the point of benefits.
pairs.neutral_text: This doesn't mean we should discourage respect for parents or make children worse instead of better. The goal is to encourage healthy competition in doing good deeds for each other. When people compete to be kind and helpful, everyone wins - both the person who gives less and the person who gives more. The only worthwhile argument between a father and son should be about who can do more good things for the other person.

pairs.stoic_text:
This life is only a prelude to eternity, where we are to expect another
original, and another state of things; we have no prospect of heaven
here but at a distance; let us therefore expect our last and decretory
hour with courage. The last (I say) to our bodies, but not to our
minds: our luggage we leave behind us, and return as naked out of the
world as we came into it. The day which we fear as our last is but
the birth-day of our eternity; and it is the only way to it. So that
what we fear as a rock, proves to be but a port, in many cases to be
desired, never to be refused; and he that dies young has only made a
quick voyage of it. Some are becalmed, others cut it away before wind;
and we live just as we sail: first, we rub our childhood out of sight;
our youth next; and then our middle age: after that follows old age,
and brings us to the common end of mankind.
pairs.neutral_text: This life is just a preparation for eternity, where we will experience something completely new and different. We cannot reach heaven while we are here on earth - it remains distant. Therefore, we should face our final hour with courage. This is the final hour for our bodies, but not for our minds. We leave our physical possessions behind and exit the world just as empty-handed as we entered it. The day we fear as our death is actually the beginning of our eternal existence, and death is the only way to reach it. What we view as a dangerous obstacle is actually a safe harbor - something that is often desirable and should never be rejected. Someone who dies young has simply completed their journey quickly. Some people's lives move slowly like a ship without wind, while others move quickly with favorable winds. We live our lives in stages similar to sailing: first we pass through childhood, then youth, then middle age, followed by old age, which brings us to the same end that all humans face.

pairs.stoic_text:
Can any man read the death of Pompey, and not be touched with an
indignation? The sound of a trumpet rouses the spirits and provokes
courage. It makes a man sad to see the shipwreck even of an enemy; and
we are much surprised by fear in other cases—all these motions are not
so much affections as preludes to them. The clashing of arms or the
beating of a drum excites a war-horse: nay, a song from Xenophantes
would make Alexander take his sword in his hand.
pairs.neutral_text: People naturally feel angry when they read about Pompey's death. A trumpet sound energizes people and makes them feel brave. Even seeing an enemy's ship sink makes people feel sad, and witnessing others' fear often surprises us. These reactions are not full emotions but early stages of emotions. War horses get excited by the sound of weapons clashing or drums beating. Similarly, a song by Xenophantes could make Alexander reach for his sword.

pairs.stoic_text:
I will never envy those that the people call great and happy. A sound
mind is not to be shaken with a popular and vain applause; nor is it
in the power of their pride to disturb the state of our happiness. An
honest man is known now-a-days by the dust he raises upon the way, and
it is become a point of honor to overrun people, and keep all at a
distance; though he that is put out of the way may perchance be happier
than he that takes it. He that would exercise a power profitable to
himself, and grievous to nobody else, let him practice it upon his
passion. They that have burnt cities, otherwise invincible, driven
armies before them, and bathed themselves in human blood, after they
have overcome all open enemies, they have been vanquished by their
lust, by their cruelty, and without any resistance.
pairs.neutral_text:
I don't envy people who are considered great and successful by the public. A rational person shouldn't be influenced by popular praise, which is often meaningless. The pride of successful people cannot affect our happiness. Today, an honest person is recognized by how much commotion he causes, and it has become fashionable to push others aside and keep everyone at a distance. However, the person who gets pushed aside might actually be happier than the one doing the pushing.

If someone wants to use power that benefits them without harming others, they should use it to control their own emotions and desires. Throughout history, people who destroyed unconquerable cities, defeated armies, and killed many people were able to overcome all external enemies. But ultimately, these same people were defeated by their own desires, cruelty, and lack of self-control.

pairs.stoic_text:
But we are not to number our friends by the _visits_ that are made us;
and to confound the decencies of _ceremony_ and _commerce_ with the
offices of _united affections_. Caius Gracchus, and after him Livius
Drusus, were the men that introduced among the Romans the fashion of
separating their visitants; some were taken into their _closet,_ others
were only admitted into the _antechamber_: and some, again, were fain
to wait in the _hall_ perhaps, or in the _court_. So that they had
their _first_, their _second,_ and their _third_ rate friends; but none
of them true: only they are called so in course, as we salute strangers
with some title or other of respect at a venture. There is no depending
upon those men that only take their compliment in their turn, and
rather slip through the door than enter at it. He will find himself in
a great mistake, that either seeks for a friend in a palace, or tries
him at a feast.
pairs.neutral_text: You shouldn't judge your friendships by how often people visit you, and you shouldn't mistake polite social customs or business relationships for genuine friendship. Caius Gracchus, and later Livius Drusus, started a Roman practice of treating visitors differently based on their social status. Some visitors were allowed into private rooms, others only into waiting areas, and some had to wait in the entrance hall or courtyard. This created a hierarchy of so-called "first-rate," "second-rate," and "third-rate" friends, but none of these relationships were actually true friendships. People were simply called "friends" as a matter of routine, the same way we politely address strangers with respectful titles. You can't rely on people who only interact with you out of social obligation and who seem to slip away quickly rather than genuinely engage. Anyone who looks for real friends in places of power or tries to evaluate friendships at social gatherings will be disappointed.

pairs.stoic_text:
There is not any benefit so glorious in itself, but it may yet be
exceedingly sweetened and improved by the _manner_ of conferring it.
The virtue, I know, rests in the _intent,_ the profit in the judicious
application of the _matter_; but the beauty and ornament of an
obligation lies in the _manner_ of it; and it is then perfect when the
dignity of the office is accompanied with all the charms and delicacies
of humanity, good-nature, and address; and with dispatch too; for he
that puts a man off from time to time, was never right at heart.
pairs.neutral_text: No benefit is so great that it cannot be made much better by how you give it. The moral value comes from your intention, and the practical value comes from using good judgment about what you give. But what makes a favor attractive is how you give it. A favor is perfect when you perform your duty while also being charming, humane, good-natured, and tactful. You should also act quickly, because someone who keeps delaying was never sincere about helping.

pairs.stoic_text:
There is not any mortal that lives free from the danger of it; for it
makes even the heavy and the good-natured to be fierce and outrageous:
it invades us like a pestilence, the lusty as well as the weak; and
it is not either strength of body, or a good diet, that can secure
us against it; nay, the most learned, and men otherwise of exemplary
sobriety, are infected with it. It is so potent a passion that Socrates
durst not trust himself with it. “Sirrah,” says he to his man, “now
would I beat you, if I were not angry with you!” There is no age or
sect of men that escapes it. Other vices take us one by one; but this,
like an _epidemical contagion_, sweeps all: men, women, and children,
princes and beggars, are carried away with it in shoals and troops as
one man.
pairs.neutral_text: No person is safe from anger. It makes even calm and good-tempered people become violent and aggressive. Anger affects everyone like a disease - both strong and weak people get it. Physical strength or eating well cannot protect you from it. Even very educated people and those who are usually well-behaved get angry. Anger is such a strong emotion that Socrates didn't trust himself when he felt it. He once told his servant, "I would hit you right now if I weren't angry with you!" People of all ages and backgrounds experience anger. Other bad behaviors affect people individually, but anger spreads like an epidemic and affects everyone - men, women, children, rich and poor people - all at once in large groups.

pairs.stoic_text:
He that uses his power as he should, takes as much delight in making
it comfortable to his people as glorious to himself. He is affable
and easy of access; his very countenance makes him the joy of his
people’s eyes, and the delight of mankind. He is beloved, defended,
and reverenced by all his subjects; and men speak as well of him in
private as in public. He is safe without guards, and the sword is
rather his ornament than his defence. In his duty, he is like that of a
good father, that sometimes gently reproves a son, sometimes threatens
him; nay, and perhaps corrects him: but no father in his right wits
will disinherit a son for the first fault; there must be many and great
offences, and only desperate consequences, that should bring him to
that decretory resolution. He will make many experiments to try if he
can reclaim him first, and nothing but the utmost despair must put him
upon extremities.
pairs.neutral_text:
A leader who uses power properly cares as much about his people's well-being as his own reputation. He is friendly and approachable, and his appearance makes people happy to see him. His subjects love, protect, and respect him. People say positive things about him both in private conversations and in public. He doesn't need bodyguards to stay safe, and he carries weapons more for ceremony than protection.

His leadership style resembles that of a good father who sometimes gently scolds his child, sometimes warns him, and occasionally punishes him. However, no sensible father would disown his son for a first mistake. Only after many serious offenses and when facing terrible outcomes would a father make such a final decision. He would try many different approaches to reform his son first, and only complete hopelessness would force him to take extreme action.

pairs.stoic_text:
The humanity and excellence of this virtue is confessed at all hands,
as well by the men of _pleasure_, and those that think every man was
made for himself, as by the Stoics, that make “man a sociable creature,
and born for the common good of mankind:” for it is of all dispositions
the most _peaceable_ and _quiet_. But before we enter any farther upon
the discourse, it should be first known what _clemency_ is, that we may
distinguish it from _pity_; which is a _weakness_, though many times
mistaken for a _virtue_: and the next thing will be, to bring the mind
to the _habit_ and _exercise_ of it.
pairs.neutral_text:
Everyone agrees that this virtue is humane and excellent. This includes people who seek pleasure and believe everyone should look out for themselves, as well as Stoics who believe humans are social beings meant to work for everyone's benefit. Of all personality traits, this one creates the most peace and calm.

Before we discuss this topic further, we need to first define what clemency is so we can tell it apart from pity. Pity is a weakness, even though people often mistake it for a virtue. After that, we will explain how to develop clemency as a habit and put it into practice.

pairs.stoic_text:
Is it not a shame, after such an example of moderation in these
creatures, that men should be yet intemperate? It were well if they
lost their stings too in their revenge, as well as the other, that they
might hurt but once, and do no mischief by their proxies. It would tire
them out, if either they were to execute all with their own hands, or
to wound others at the peril of their own lives.
pairs.neutral_text: It's disappointing that humans are still excessive and immoderate when these creatures show such restraint. It would be good if people also lost their ability to harm others after using it once, just like these creatures lose their stings. This would mean they could only hurt someone once and couldn't cause additional harm through other people acting on their behalf. People would become exhausted from revenge if they had to carry out all their harmful actions personally or if harming others put their own lives at risk.

pairs.stoic_text:
How vain a thing is it for us to enter upon projects, and to say to
ourselves, “Well, I will go build, purchase, discharge such offices,
settle my affairs, and then retire!” We are all of us born to the same
casualties—all equally frail and uncertain of to-morrow. At the very
altar where we pray for life, we learn to die, by seeing the sacrifices
killed before us. But there is no need of a wound, or searching the
heart for it, when the noose of a cord, or the smothering of a pillow
will do the work. All things have their seasons—they begin, they
increase, and they die. The heavens and the earth grow old, and are
appointed their periods.
pairs.neutral_text: It is pointless for us to make long-term plans and tell ourselves, "I will build, buy things, complete my work responsibilities, organize my life, and then relax." We all face the same risks in life—we are all equally weak and don't know what will happen tomorrow. When we go to religious services and pray to live longer, we are reminded of death by witnessing animal sacrifices. Death doesn't require serious injury or heart problems—it can happen from something as simple as choking or suffocation. Everything follows a natural cycle—things start, grow, and end. Even the universe ages and will eventually come to an end.

pairs.stoic_text:
It cost Julius Cæsar his life by the disappointment of his insatiable
companions; and yet he reserved nothing of all that he got to himself
but the liberty of disposing of it. There is no benefit so large
but malignity will still lessen it; none so narrow, which a good
interpretation will not enlarge. No man shall ever be grateful that
views a benefit on the wrong side, or takes a good office by the wrong
handle. The avaricious man is naturally ungrateful, for he never thinks
he has enough, but, without considering what he has, only minds what
he covets. Some pretend want of power to make a competent return, and
you shall find in others a kind of graceless modesty, that makes a man
ashamed of requiting an obligation, because it is a confession that he
has received one.
pairs.neutral_text: Julius Caesar was killed because his greedy followers were disappointed with what they received, even though he kept nothing for himself except the right to decide how to distribute his wealth. People will always find ways to criticize even generous benefits, while good intentions can make even small gifts seem valuable. Anyone who focuses on the negative aspects of a favor or misunderstands a good deed will never feel grateful. Greedy people are naturally ungrateful because they always want more - they don't appreciate what they have and only think about what they want next. Some people claim they don't have the ability to properly repay favors. Others feel embarrassed about repaying debts because doing so would mean admitting they needed help in the first place.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is not prudent to deny a pardon to any man, without first examining
if we stand not in need of it ourselves; for it may be our lot to ask
it, even at his feet to whom we refuse it. But we are willing enough to
do what we are very unwilling to suffer. It is unreasonable to charge
public vices upon particular persons; for we are all of us wicked,
and that which we blame in others we find in ourselves. It is not a
paleness in one, or a leanness in another, but a pestilence that has
laid hold upon all.
pairs.neutral_text:
You shouldn't refuse to forgive someone without first considering whether you might need forgiveness yourself. You could end up needing to ask for forgiveness from the same person you refused to forgive. People are willing to do things they wouldn't want done to them.

It's unfair to blame individuals for problems that affect society as a whole. Everyone has flaws, and the things we criticize in others exist in us too. The issue isn't that one person has this problem and another has that problem - it's that everyone is affected by the same underlying human weaknesses.

pairs.stoic_text:
“Here follows now,” says Tacitus, “the death of Seneca, to Nero’s great
satisfaction; not so much for any pregnant proof against him that he
was of Piso’s conspiracy; but Nero was resolved to do that by the sword
which he could not effect by poison. For it is reported, that Nero
had corrupted Cleonicus (a freeman of Seneca’s) to give his master
poison, which did not succeed. Whether that the servant had discovered
it to his master, or that Seneca, by his own caution and jealousy, had
avoided it; for he lived only upon a simple diet, as the fruits of the
earth, and his drink was most commonly river water.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's what Tacitus says happened next: Seneca died, which made Nero very happy. This wasn't because Nero had strong evidence that Seneca was part of Piso's plot against him. Instead, Nero had decided to kill Seneca with a sword since he had failed to poison him earlier.

According to reports, Nero had bribed Cleonicus, one of Seneca's freed slaves, to poison his master. But the poisoning didn't work. This might have been because the servant told Seneca about the plan, or because Seneca was already being careful and suspicious. Seneca ate only simple foods like fruits and vegetables, and usually drank only river water.

pairs.stoic_text:
In all these cases the mind rather suffers than acts, and therefore it
is not an affection _to be moved_, but _to give way_ to that motion,
and to follow willingly what was started by chance—these are not
affections, but impulses of the body. The bravest man in the world may
look pale when he puts on his armor, his knees knock, and his heart
work before the battle is joined: but these are only _motions_; whereas
_anger_ is an _excursion_, and proposes revenge or punishment, which
cannot be without the mind. As fear flies, so anger assaults; and it is
not possible to resolve, either upon violence or caution, without the
concurrence of the will.
pairs.neutral_text:
In all these situations, the mind is passive rather than active. Therefore, being moved by something is not an emotion, but giving in to that movement and willingly following what started by accident—these are not emotions, but physical responses of the body. 

The bravest person may turn pale when putting on armor, have shaking knees, and feel their heart racing before a battle begins. However, these are just physical reactions. Anger, on the other hand, is an active response that seeks revenge or punishment, and this cannot happen without the mind being involved. 

Fear makes people run away, while anger makes people attack. It is impossible to decide on either violence or being careful without the will being involved.

pairs.stoic_text:
The particularity does much, but yet the same thing may receive
a different estimate from several persons; for there are ways of
marking and recommending it in such a manner, that if the same _good
office_ be done to twenty people, every one of them shall reckon
himself peculiarly obliged as a cunning whore, if she has a thousand
sweethearts, will persuade every one of them she loves him best. But
this is rather the artifice of conversation than the virtue of it.
pairs.neutral_text: Individual circumstances matter significantly, but the same action can be viewed differently by different people. There are methods of presenting and promoting something so that if the same favor is done for twenty people, each person will feel they received special treatment - similar to how a manipulative prostitute with many clients will convince each one that he is her favorite. However, this represents skillful manipulation in social interaction rather than genuine virtue.

pairs.stoic_text:
Did not Cato, in the last night of his life, take Plato to bed with
him, with his sword at his bed’s head; the one that he might have death
at his will, the other, that he might have it in his power; being
resolved that no man should be able to say, either that he killed or
that he saved Cato? So soon as he had composed his thoughts, he took
his sword; “Fortune,” says he, “I have hitherto fought for my country’s
liberty, and for my own, and only that I might live free among freemen;
but the cause is now lost, and Cato safe.” With that word he cast
himself upon his sword; and after the physicians that pressed in upon
him had bound up his wound, he tore it up again, and expired with the
same greatness of soul that he lived. But these are the examples, you
will say, of men famous in their generations.
pairs.neutral_text:
On Cato's last night alive, he kept Plato's writings and his sword by his bed. The sword was there so he could choose to die if he wanted to. The book was there so he could choose to live if he wanted to. He wanted to make sure that no one else could claim they either killed him or saved him - the decision would be entirely his own.

After he had thought everything through, he picked up his sword and said, "Fortune, I have fought until now for my country's freedom and my own freedom, so that I could live as a free man among other free people. But that cause has failed, and Cato is now safe." Then he stabbed himself with the sword. When doctors rushed in and bandaged his wound, he tore the bandages off and died with the same strong character he had shown throughout his life. 

But you might argue that these are just examples of men who were already famous in their time.
